Instead of damning capitalism, learn why it actually helps drive these efforts instead of tearing it down. This is excellent work, and I truly hope the Collective Project succeeds in it's mission, limbs for people without is the most admirable use for 3d printing yet and more do need to be involved..

Now the sad comment, I realise a lot of people aren't going to like what I'm about to say, but it needs to be said.

Microsoft are up to some really bad things at the moment, things that, in a sane world, they would be sanctioned for and this project is going to give them good publicity, that doesn't outweight the damage they are doing and will ultimately distract from their transgressions in bigger issues, yes, unfortunately there are bigger issues than giving children limbs, I wish we lived in a world where that wasn't the case, but with everything going on, it simply is, and it does make me sad having to say that.

I'm due to get a printer in soon, and it's the only thing stopping me from getting involved with this wonderful project. As was always my intention, I'll be doing whatever I am able to do on my end, on my own, or if I find a similar but unburdened project, but I won't do anything that is, in any way, a benefit to Microsoft. Should, in the future, the Collective Project unshackle themselves from Microsoft then I will come running to sign up, but not until then. As I said, sadly, there are bigger issues here, and for there to actually be bigger issues than the goals this project wants to fulfil, that statement alone surely should be taken seriously.

If anyone in the project would like to test Microsoft's commitment, motivations and actual levels of caring, tell them you're looking into bringing Apple, Linux or any other company wishing to split the kudos, in to the project also, and watch all MS support disappear.

I apologise for making this statement but do wish to say that I have hope for your success.

Great that they are making a cheaper arm. If ads help pay for that, that's fine. When that lets a kid (or adult) have a working hand and arm, that is so, so fantastic. It is vital for it to look and feel and work, real and normal, like everyone else's.
I'm legally blind, vision-impaired, born that way. So I grew up "different" from all the other kids and teased or bullied almost daily up until high school. Kids, even adults, don't realize what even little stuff can do to a handicapped kid (or adult). To be able to function like an average person, to do what everyone else takes completely for granted...that is why the older boy in the video is so thankful, so overjoyed. We are a long, long way off from "bionic eyes" or any sort of biological transplant, because the eyes are part of the nervous system. We'd have to understand more about how nerves transmit information and how the brain processes it, to know how the eyes work, to be able to remedy this. But there's progress for artificial limbs, hearing, and maybe for paraplegics and quads. To bring the cost down this much means they can devote a lot more to how the parts work, to miniaturization, and to customize the appearance for a person who needs the limb. Really, really awesome.

Wow, this is amazing! I run an open source electronics company and I have been trying to tell people of all the great stuff we can do with 3D printers and open source hardware. I like the humanist/noncapitalist vibe they have of providing free arms. This tech is so positive it is a great example of something we can decouple from the capitalist system using a donation-funded model. If they register as a nonprofit, wealthy people looking to do good can also benefit from a tax break on the money they contribute to the cause. Plus it's just an amazing thing to do for young children who can't necessarily afford custom engineered robot arms. We have the tech to make people whole again and providing it for free is really the best way, so everyone who needs one can get their life back. So yeah... these people are great. What's really disappointing, however, is how microsoft seems to have completely co-opted these people's message to sell some lame software. As an engineer I wanted to get in touch with these people and help contribute to their efforts, but I seem to have encountered a wall of microsoft advertisements that completely obsure any links to these people's good work. Neither the end of the video nor the links in the description include any direct link to these great people's work, seemingly because microsoft has bought their name for a handful of cash. It's great for a wealthy organization to connect with people who can benefit from the cash, but they're actually interfering with this group's main goal by obscuring their contact info for people like myself who want to help. I don't use microsoft products, and I'm not interested in their ads. I just want to help. Can you please include a link to these amazing people's work directly in this video? Even a quick google search is leading me back to articles that only applaud Microsoft's involvement, but do not focus on these engineers. Please link to their work in this video's description, they deserve it. I will keep looking, but people shouldn't need to. Great video though, I will subscribe!

I understand the guy's statement that "no one should profit from a child with no arms", but I feel if you're not careful you can create a financial problem for yourself that could hinder this lovely goal.  I agree that this is a very noble cause with good intentions, but we cannot be blinded by the notion that no profit can be made during a noble cause.  If this were to become a thing, then someone has to pay for the printer and the supplies, and whoever mans the printer probably wants to get paid so they can eat.  So someone will have to profit somewhere in this chain of events and someone will have to front the bill.  If we don't want to make families pay directly, then we're either looking at insurance companies or government funding.  Both options will still rely on a large group funding this whole process.  Just food for thought.

Prosthetic limbs could be so much more advanced than they are.. the sad fact is advancement = investment, but advancement is only possible with the prospect of profit, at least from the traditional capitalist perspective. This is why until the maker revolution, prosthetic's have been the realm of a few small companies, which is why they have been so expensive.. 3D printing has allowed rapid prototyping, so engineers can revise much faster than they could traditionally. I feel that there isn't one thing that can be pointed to for the great advances we are seeing, it's rather a fantastic cumulative effect of the right technology becoming CHEAP (China) and PRACTICAL (Micro controllers and lithium batteries along with cheap servos etc) plus the power of the internet, and above all, the dedication of people who do this to HELP OTHERS rather than attempt tp achieve a profit for a faceless company. 

Well done to all involved, and good luck in the future!

What we are complaining about is that the people in the video state at about 5:41 that they "don't feel like people should profit off a child without an arm." That's great, but not long before that (5:00) they talk about Microsoft OneNote, and how they need funding. This makes me feel like Microsoft might not actually be funding them at all, and that what we have is some inappropriate product placement.

And that's the key word, inappropriate. The project it self is fricken awesome! Helping handicapped kids get free/cheap prosthetic arms. But we have a forced in ad (and it really does feel forced, especially with the guy they were talking to online, his tone less enthusiastic, his eyes darting back and fourth as if reading from a script in another window), which I feel goes against their statement about people profiting off of children. Don't be fooled, OneNote may be free, but that's not what Microsoft is betting on. They are still trying to make money, and they're betting that you will buy more Microsoft products because of OneNote. Making money off this project.

Nothing is free. I truly do hope at the very least Microsoft is funding the project. It is a noble project, but the forced ad in the middle leaves many with a bad taste in their mouth. For me at least, this has nothing to do with anit-Microsoft, this has to do with how inappropriate it all was. Had it been ANY company who did this I think all of us would have the same reaction.

As for the ad at the end of the video, that is by no means unique to Veritasium. It's is sad that they have to do that just to make a living. It does make everything seem less genuine as well. And that is my two cents. I encourage thoughtful discussion.

While 3D printing is cheap and accessible for one off projects like this, it's cheaper to produce plastic in bulk in other ways. Everyone seems to be saying that 3D printing is so cheap, but there's a reason that all the cheap plastic products from around the world still aren't being 3D printed. It's cheaper to produce plastic products in other ways.

3D printing is fantastic for prototyping, but not for mass production. With a project like this, it makes more sense to mass produce rather than 3D print.

Before I'm accused of being completely cynical, let it be known that I appreciate this work and it is undoubtedly going to be a force for good. My main concern is with the falsity that 3D printed products are cheaper to produce. Sure they're cheaper to design and prototype, but they're most definitely not cheaper in mass production contexts, and it would be cheaper to buy a product produced in a different way than to print it yourself.

I agree that every child should have access to a prosthetic, but I don't think that it's necessarily good to make it purely non-profit. Over time, engineers should be incentivized to hone the technology to create even better prosthetics which are also more affordable. Making it charity-funded and volunteer based will actually stunt further advances and innovations. For those that cannot afford it, I think it would be better to raise money to purchase them from said company and to develop flexible insurance/financial options. This will optimize quality and price over time for the consumer as well as making the industry more sustainable. I think modulating the parts of the arm would help increase cost efficiency. Like, the child would get one elbow joint that can be attached to new sockets as the child grows and new forearms/hand prosthesis to match growth and tech advances. Plus if one part fails, the others can still be used, and the failed component could easily be replaced. This could also lead to standardizing  forearm and hand sizes to help make fits quicker, and opens up the possibility for cost reduced secondhand exchange. Though I'm not sure how the community feels about that sort of thing.

Gotta be honest, I don't think they've solved a problem that others couldn't, I think they've just made a cheapo version of the real thing, and it's not even an advancement in anything, big deal, they are getting on the 3D printing hype train 5 years late. Like, it's fine for giving kids confidence and it's clearly a good thing as it makes them happy, but it looks like you could fall and all of the fingers would just break into pieces, and the demo of it gripping was on an empty water bottle? Is that all it can grasp and lift? Or was that just all they had at the time to demo it to the millions that could see this video?

The real problem is the robotic arms that cost 50 grand only cost so much because of the research and development that goes in to them, and there is no infrastructure in place to manufacture them on a large scale. And the companies that are making these arms aren't looking to sell them on a large scale, instead they are just constantly making new versions and improving, and there is nothing special about them mechanically, the physical materials and technology are going to be pretty cheap. So if we want people to have well built functioning arms then somebody needs to push the development of bionic arms and get them down to a reasonable price, and while it's great for these kids, in the big picture making a barely functional cheapo version out of plastic is like putting a plaster on a knife wound.
